titlestmt.subtitle: Records of the British Admiralty, 1811-1813, at the Lilly Library, Indiana University
titlestmt.author: Mary McSparran

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-02-18 22:03:14 -0500.

change.item: Batch update to change subject links.

did.abstract: The Gt. Brit. Admiralty mss., 1811-1813, consists of contemporary copies and duplicates of orders and letters to Rear Admiral Robert Stopford, 1768-1847, and Rear Admiral Charles Tyler, 1760-1835, commanders-in-chief at the Cape of Good Hope.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
Many collections are housed offsite; retrieval requires advance notice. Please make an appointment a minimum of one week in advance of your visit.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Photography and digitization may be restricted for some collections. Copyright restrictions may apply. Before publishing, researchers are responsible for securing permission from all applicable rights holders, then filling out the Permission to Publish form.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The British Admiralty, originally known as the Office of the Admiralty and Marine Affairs, was the government department responsible for the command of the British Royal Navy until 1964, when that power reverted to the Crown.

The Cape of Good Hope, also known as the Cape Colony, was a British colony in present-day South Africa. The Cape was under Dutch rule from 1652 to 1795 and again from 1803 to 1806. The colony was occupied by Britain following the Battle of Blaauwberg in 1806, and the Anglo-Dutch Treaty of 1814 affirmed British possession. The Cape of Good Hope became self-governing in 1872, united with three other colonies to form the Union of South Africa in 1910, transitioned into a sovereign state in 1931, and became the Republic of South Africa in 1961.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of contemporary copies and duplicates of orders and letters to the commanders-in-chief at the Cape of Good Hope, Rear Admiral Robert Stopford (1768-1847) and Rear Admiral Charles Tyler (1760-1835). Most of the documents were signed by Sir John Barrow (1764-1848), secretary of the admiralty. Included are twenty-nine printed documents signed and eight printed documents unsigned.
For digitized content, see Digital Collections.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged following original order.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Gt. Brit. Admiralty mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.
